description:
Saccopteryx bilineata, commonly known as the greater yellow bat or greater yellow sac-winged bat, is a species of bat belonging to the family Emballonuridae. It is found in Central and South America, ranging from Mexico to Brazil.

The Saccopteryx bilineata is a small to medium-sized bat, with a body length of around 5-6 inches (12-15 cm) and a wingspan of approximately 12-14 inches (30-35 cm). Its fur is generally yellowish-brown or grayish-brown in color, with a distinct dark-colored stripe running along the dorsal (upper) surface of each wing membrane.

One of the distinctive features of this species is the presence of a small, pouch-like structure on the underside of each wing, known as a sac. These sacs are believed to be involved in scent marking and communication behaviors, as the bats use them to release pheromones.

Saccopteryx bilineata is primarily insectivorous, feeding on a variety of flying insects such as moths, beetles, and flies. They are known to forage in both open and forested areas, using their echolocation abilities to locate and capture their prey.

These bats are generally colonial, roosting in small to medium-sized groups in caves, hollow trees, and abandoned buildings. They are known to exhibit complex social behaviors, including vocal communication and group foraging.

The conservation status of Saccopteryx bilineata is classified as "Least Concern" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as the species is widespread and has a relatively stable population throughout its range.
